best_practices: Provide a clear conceptual direction or theme for the skill to interpret visually
Request specific aesthetic styles if you have preferences (Brutalist, Minimalist, Geometric, etc.)
Specify output format preference (.pdf for print-ready, .png for digital display)
Ask for multiple pages if you want a cohesive series rather than a single composition
Trust the skill's design philosophy approach - it creates the aesthetic framework first, then expresses it
Review the generated .md design philosophy file to understand the aesthetic principles used
Request refinements focusing on existing elements rather than adding more complexity
Emphasize sophistication and craftsmanship in your prompts to get museum-quality results
anti_patterns: Don't ask for photorealistic imagery or literal illustrations - this skill excels at abstract visual design
Avoid requesting heavy text content or explanatory paragraphs - text should be minimal and visual
Don't expect cartoony or amateur aesthetics - the skill is calibrated for sophisticated, professional work
Avoid asking to copy specific existing artists' styles verbatim due to copyright concerns
Don't request interactive elements, animations, or video - output is static PDF/PNG only
Avoid over-specifying layout details - let the design philosophy guide compositional choices

faq.question: What's the difference between this and asking Claude to generate images directly?
faq.answer: This skill follows a two-phase design methodology: first creating a sophisticated design philosophy/aesthetic movement, then expressing it through expert-level visual composition. It emphasizes museum-quality craftsmanship, sophisticated typography using professional fonts, and minimal text integrated as visual elements rather than explanatory content.

faq.question: Can I use the output for commercial purposes?
faq.answer: The skill is licensed under Apache 2.0, and all included fonts use the SIL Open Font License which permits commercial use. However, you should verify that generated designs don't inadvertently reference copyrighted material and review licensing terms yourself.

faq.question: How do I get the best results?
faq.answer: Provide conceptual direction rather than detailed layout instructions. Let the skill develop the aesthetic philosophy, then request refinements if needed. Emphasize the sophistication level you want (e.g., 'museum-quality,' 'editorial design,' 'brutalist poster') to calibrate the output.

faq.question: What file formats are supported?
faq.answer: The skill outputs .pdf files (ideal for print-ready work) and .png files (for digital display), plus .md files documenting the design philosophy used.

faq.question: Can I request specific fonts or color palettes?
faq.answer: Yes, you can specify preferences, though the skill will interpret them through its design philosophy framework. It has access to 30+ professional open-source fonts in the canvas-fonts directory.

faq.question: How does the 'subtle reference' feature work?
faq.answer: The skill embeds conceptual threads within the visual composition - like a jazz musician quoting another song. Those familiar with the subject may intuitively feel it, while others simply experience a masterful abstract design. This adds depth without being literal.

dependencies: Access to 30 professional open-source fonts (SIL OFL licensed)
